domain: Domain 5: Social & Cultural Bases of Behavior

questions.stem: In Festinger and Carlsmith's (1959) classic study, participants who were paid $1 to tell the next participant that a boring task was enjoyable subsequently rated the task as more enjoyable than participants paid $20. Which mechanism best explains this finding?

options.text: The $1 group experienced greater external justification for their counterattitudinal behavior, reducing their need for attitude change
The $1 group had insufficient external justification for their counterattitudinal behavior, creating dissonance that was reduced through attitude change
The $20 group experienced reactance against the large payment, causing them to devalue the task as a form of resistance
The $1 group formed stronger memories of the task due to the minimal reward, leading to more positive evaluations through the mere exposure effect

questions.explanation: This is the classic demonstration of the insufficient justification effect in cognitive dissonance theory. When people engage in counterattitudinal behavior (saying a boring task was fun) with minimal external justification ($1), they experience dissonance between their behavior ('I said it was fun') and their attitude ('It was boring'). Because the $1 is insufficient to justify the lie, they reduce dissonance by changing their attitude toward the task. The $20 group had sufficient external justification ('I said it was fun because I was well paid'), so no dissonance was aroused and no attitude change occurred.

questions.stem: A client in therapy reports that she initially had no strong feelings about jogging, but after her therapist encouraged her to jog daily for two weeks as a behavioral intervention, she now reports genuinely enjoying it. Bem's self-perception theory would explain this attitude change by proposing that:

options.text: The repeated behavior created cognitive dissonance between her neutral attitude and her jogging behavior, motivating attitude change to reduce the tension
She inferred her positive attitude toward jogging by observing her own voluntary behavior of jogging daily, much as an outside observer would
The mere exposure effect from repeated jogging sessions increased her familiarity with the activity, leading to greater liking
The effort she invested in jogging triggered effort justification, causing her to value jogging more to justify the energy expenditure

questions.explanation: Self-perception theory (Bem, 1972) proposes that when attitudes are weak, ambiguous, or nonexistent, people infer their attitudes by observing their own behavior and the circumstances surrounding it. Since this client had no strong prior attitude about jogging, she observed her consistent jogging behavior and inferred 'I must enjoy jogging because I keep doing it.' This is distinct from cognitive dissonance, which requires a strong prior attitude that conflicts with behavior. Self-perception theory applies when initial attitudes are weak or absent.

questions.stem: According to the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991), which component can influence behavior BOTH indirectly through behavioral intention AND directly without being mediated by intention?

options.text: Attitude toward the behavior
Subjective norms
Perceived behavioral control
Past behavior frequency

questions.explanation: In the Theory of Planned Behavior, perceived behavioral control (one's belief about the ease or difficulty of performing the behavior, similar to Bandura's self-efficacy) has a unique dual pathway to behavior. It influences behavior indirectly through its effect on behavioral intention, AND it can also influence behavior directly when actual control is limited. For example, even with strong intentions, if a person perceives they cannot perform the behavior, they are less likely to do so. Attitude toward the behavior and subjective norms only influence behavior through intention. Past behavior is not a formal component of the TPB.

questions.stem: A researcher finds that participants who underwent a painful and humiliating initiation to join a group rated the group as significantly more attractive than participants who underwent a mild initiation. This finding is best explained by which cognitive dissonance paradigm?

options.text: Induced compliance
Free-choice paradigm
Effort justification
Belief disconfirmation

questions.explanation: Effort justification is a cognitive dissonance paradigm in which people who undergo significant effort, pain, or difficulty to attain a goal come to value that goal more highly. The cognition 'I suffered to join this group' is dissonant with 'the group isn't that great,' so dissonance is reduced by enhancing the perceived attractiveness of the group. This was demonstrated by Aronson and Mills (1959) with severe vs. mild initiation conditions. Induced compliance involves being persuaded to act against one's attitudes. The free-choice paradigm involves spreading of alternatives after making a choice.

questions.stem: According to the functional approach to attitudes (Katz, 1960), a person who holds strongly negative attitudes toward a minority group because those attitudes protect against feelings of personal inadequacy is exhibiting an attitude that serves which function?

options.text: Knowledge function
Utilitarian function
Value-expressive function
Ego-defensive function

questions.explanation: Katz (1960) proposed four attitude functions. The ego-defensive function describes attitudes that protect the individual from internal conflicts or threats to self-esteem. Prejudice that serves as a defense against personal inadequacy (projecting negative qualities onto an outgroup to feel superior) exemplifies this function. Importantly, ego-defensive attitudes cannot be changed through rational arguments targeting the knowledge function; instead, the underlying anxiety must be addressed. The utilitarian function helps maximize rewards, the knowledge function organizes the world, and the value-expressive function communicates identity.

questions.stem: Steele's self-affirmation theory (1988) proposes an alternative mechanism for resolving cognitive dissonance. Which of the following statements accurately describe self-affirmation theory? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: Dissonance arises from a threat to overall self-integrity rather than from the logical inconsistency between cognitions per se
Affirming an important self-concept in a domain completely unrelated to the source of dissonance can reduce dissonance without changing the inconsistent cognition
Self-affirmation can only reduce dissonance when the affirmed value is directly related to the domain of the inconsistency
Self-affirmation has been applied to health behavior interventions, where affirming personal values before receiving threatening health information reduces defensive processing
Self-affirmation theory replaces cognitive dissonance theory by demonstrating that attitude change never occurs in response to inconsistency

questions.explanation: Steele's self-affirmation theory proposes that the discomfort of dissonance stems from a threat to one's sense of overall self-integrity, not from logical inconsistency itself. Therefore, affirming any important aspect of self-worth -- even in a completely unrelated domain -- can restore self-integrity and reduce dissonance without changing the inconsistent cognition. This has been applied to health psychology: having people affirm their values before receiving threatening health messages reduces defensive processing. The theory does not replace dissonance theory but offers an alternative resolution pathway.

questions.stem: Research on the attitude-behavior relationship has identified several factors that strengthen the consistency between attitudes and behaviors. Which of the following conditions increase the predictive validity of attitudes for behavior? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: The attitude was formed through direct personal experience with the attitude object rather than secondhand information
The attitude and the behavior are measured at the same level of specificity (principle of compatibility)
Situational pressures to behave in a particular way are strong and clearly defined
The individual is in a state of heightened self-awareness when the behavior occurs
The attitude is highly accessible and comes to mind quickly and easily when the attitude object is encountered

questions.explanation: Several factors increase attitude-behavior consistency: (1) Direct experience produces stronger, more accessible attitudes. (2) The principle of compatibility (Ajzen & Fishbein) states that specific attitudes predict specific behaviors better than general attitudes. (3) Self-awareness increases alignment between attitudes and behavior. (4) Highly accessible attitudes are better behavioral predictors. Strong situational pressures actually DECREASE the attitude-behavior link because behavior is determined more by the situation than by the person's attitude (this is why low situational pressure is a moderator favoring attitude-behavior consistency).

questions.stem: Which of the following are accurate distinctions between Bem's self-perception theory and Festinger's cognitive dissonance theory? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: Cognitive dissonance theory posits an aversive arousal state that motivates attitude change, while self-perception theory posits a calm, rational inference process
Self-perception theory better explains attitude change when the person had strong prior attitudes that contradict their behavior
Dissonance theory better accounts for counterattitudinal behavior when pre-existing attitudes are strong and clearly defined
Self-perception theory better explains attitude formation when prior attitudes are weak, ambiguous, or nonexistent
Research by Fazio, Zanna, and Cooper (1977) suggests that both theories are valid but apply in different circumstances

questions.explanation: Both theories make similar behavioral predictions but differ in their proposed mechanisms. Dissonance theory assumes an aversive arousal state (tension from inconsistency) that motivates attitude change, while self-perception theory proposes a calm inferential process. Research by Fazio, Zanna, and Cooper (1977) reconciled the two: dissonance theory applies when behavior contradicts strong prior attitudes (creating genuine arousal), while self-perception theory applies when attitudes are weak or ambiguous (no arousal needed, just self-observation). Option B is incorrect because self-perception theory is NOT the better explanation when strong prior attitudes exist.

questions.stem: Regarding implicit attitudes and the Implicit Association Test (IAT), which of the following statements are supported by current research? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: Implicit attitudes are automatic, unconscious evaluations that can differ significantly from a person's explicit self-reported attitudes
The IAT measures the strength of associations between concepts by comparing response latencies across paired categorization tasks
Implicit attitudes are better predictors of spontaneous, uncontrolled behaviors such as nonverbal behavior during interracial interactions
Explicit attitudes are better predictors of deliberate, controlled behaviors such as carefully considered voting decisions
If an individual's explicit and implicit attitudes diverge, the implicit attitude is always the more accurate reflection of their true feelings

questions.explanation: Implicit attitudes are automatic evaluations that can diverge from explicit attitudes. The IAT (Greenwald et al., 1998) measures these by comparing response times in paired categorization tasks. Research supports a dual-attitude model: implicit attitudes better predict spontaneous behaviors (nonverbal behavior, snap judgments), while explicit attitudes better predict deliberate, controlled behaviors (voting, planned decisions). The MODE model (Fazio, 1990) explains this based on motivation and opportunity for deliberate processing. Option E is incorrect -- neither type is inherently more 'true'; each predicts different types of behavior.

questions.stem: According to the ABC model of attitudes, which of the following scenarios illustrate situations in which the three attitude components (Affective, Behavioral, Cognitive) are NOT aligned? (Select ALL that apply.)

options.text: A person knows intellectually that flying is statistically safe but feels intense anxiety when boarding a plane and avoids air travel
A person believes smoking is harmful, feels disgusted by cigarettes, and never smokes
A psychologist explicitly endorses egalitarian values but shows implicit racial bias on the IAT and exhibits subtle avoidance behaviors during cross-racial interactions
A student reports positive beliefs about studying, enjoys learning, and studies consistently
A person cognitively evaluates a new food as nutritious and decides to try it, but experiences a strong negative emotional reaction upon tasting it

questions.explanation: The ABC model identifies three components: Affective (emotions), Behavioral (actions/tendencies), and Cognitive (beliefs/thoughts). When these components conflict, internal inconsistency exists. In option A, the cognitive component (flying is safe) conflicts with the affective (anxiety) and behavioral (avoidance). In option C, the cognitive/explicit attitude (egalitarianism) conflicts with the implicit affective evaluation (bias) and behavior (avoidance). In option E, the cognitive (nutritious) and behavioral (willingness to try) conflict with the affective (negative emotional reaction). Options B and D show alignment among all three components.

questions.stem: For each cognitive dissonance paradigm, select the researcher(s) who conducted the original demonstration.
questions.explanation: Each classic dissonance paradigm is associated with specific researchers: (1) Induced compliance was demonstrated by Festinger & Carlsmith (1959) in the $1/$20 study. (2) The free-choice paradigm (post-decisional dissonance and spreading of alternatives) was introduced by Jack Brehm (1956). (3) Effort justification (severe vs. mild initiation) was demonstrated by Aronson & Mills (1959). (4) Belief disconfirmation was studied by Festinger, Riecken, and Schachter in their field study of a doomsday cult, published as 'When Prophecy Fails' (1956).

questions.stem: For each attitude measurement technique, select the characteristic that BEST distinguishes it from the others.

columns.text: Respondents rate agreement with statements on a numerical scale
Respondents rate objects on bipolar adjective pairs capturing evaluative, potency, and activity dimensions
Statements have predetermined scale values; respondents endorse those they agree with
Participants believe a device detects their true attitudes, motivating honest responding

questions.explanation: Each attitude measurement method has a distinct defining feature: Likert scales use agreement ratings on numerical scales (e.g., 1-5 from Strongly Disagree to Strongly Agree) and are the most common explicit measure. Osgood's semantic differential uses bipolar adjective pairs (good-bad, strong-weak, active-passive) to capture three dimensions of meaning. Thurstone scales use judge-weighted statements with predetermined scale values. The bogus pipeline is a technique where participants are led to believe a physiological device can detect their true attitudes, reducing social desirability bias on self-report measures.

questions.stem: For each type of attitude, select ALL behavior types it is most likely to predict according to dual-attitude research and the MODE model.

columns.text: Deliberate voting decisions after careful consideration
Spontaneous nonverbal behavior during interracial interactions
Planned dietary choices based on health beliefs
Written policy statements prepared with reflection time

questions.explanation: According to the MODE model (Fazio, 1990) and dual-attitude research: Explicit attitudes predict deliberate, controlled behaviors where the person has both motivation and opportunity for careful processing -- such as carefully considered voting decisions, planned dietary choices, and prepared policy statements. Implicit attitudes predict spontaneous, uncontrolled behaviors where there is limited time or motivation for deliberative processing -- such as nonverbal behavior during interracial interactions and snap judgments about unfamiliar people.

questions.stem: For each cognitive consistency theory, select ALL characteristics that accurately describe it.

columns.text: Focuses on consistency between cognitions, especially after counterattitudinal behavior
Analyzes consistency in person-other-object (P-O-X) triadic relationships
Proposes dissonance can be reduced by affirming self-worth in an unrelated domain
Predicts that insufficient external justification leads to greater attitude change
System is balanced when the product of the three relationship signs is positive

questions.explanation: Each cognitive consistency theory has distinct features: Festinger's cognitive dissonance theory focuses on consistency between cognitions (especially after counterattitudinal behavior) and uniquely predicts the insufficient justification effect. Heider's balance theory analyzes P-O-X triads and uses a multiplicative rule (the product of the three relationship signs must be positive for balance). Steele's self-affirmation theory adds to dissonance theory by proposing that dissonance can be reduced through affirming self-worth in any domain, not just the one creating the inconsistency.

questions.stem:
Complete the following summary of the Theory of Planned Behavior:

According to Ajzen (1991), the immediate determinant of behavior is {{blank1}}. This is predicted by three components: {{blank2}} (one's evaluation of the behavior), {{blank3}} (perceived social pressure regarding the behavior), and {{blank4}} (one's belief about the ease or difficulty of performing the behavior, which is conceptually similar to Bandura's concept of {{blank5}}).

options.text: behavioral intention
attitude strength
self-efficacy
attitude toward the behavior
attitude toward the object
implicit attitude
subjective norms
descriptive norms
injunctive norms
perceived behavioral control
locus of control
outcome expectancy
self-efficacy
self-regulation
self-concept

questions.explanation: The Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991) proposes that the proximal determinant of behavior is behavioral intention, which is predicted by three components: (1) attitude toward the behavior (not the object generally), (2) subjective norms (perceived social expectations), and (3) perceived behavioral control (belief about the ease/difficulty of the behavior). Perceived behavioral control is conceptually similar to Bandura's self-efficacy. Note: the TPB predicts behavioral intention, not behavior directly, though perceived behavioral control also has a direct path to behavior.

questions.stem:
Complete the following comparison of cognitive dissonance theory and self-perception theory:

Festinger's cognitive dissonance theory proposes that counterattitudinal behavior creates an {{blank1}} state of arousal that motivates attitude change. In contrast, Bem's self-perception theory proposes a {{blank2}} process in which people simply infer their attitudes from their behavior. Research by Fazio, Zanna, and Cooper (1977) suggests that dissonance theory better explains attitude change when {{blank3}}, while self-perception theory better explains attitude formation when {{blank4}}. One important prediction unique to self-perception theory is the {{blank5}}, in which providing external rewards for intrinsically motivated behavior decreases intrinsic motivation.

options.text: aversive
pleasant
neutral
calm, inferential
emotionally charged
unconscious, automatic
strong prior attitudes are contradicted by behavior
no prior attitudes exist
behavior is externally rewarded
prior attitudes are weak or nonexistent
prior attitudes are strong and well-defined
the behavior is publicly observable
overjustification effect
insufficient justification effect
effort justification effect

questions.explanation: Cognitive dissonance theory involves an aversive arousal state that motivates change, while self-perception theory proposes a calm, inferential process. Fazio et al. (1977) found that dissonance theory better explains situations with strong prior attitudes, and self-perception theory is more applicable when attitudes are weak or absent. The overjustification effect (Lepper, Greene, & Nisbett, 1973) is a self-perception prediction: external rewards for already-enjoyed activities lead the person to infer 'I must be doing this for the reward, not because I enjoy it,' reducing intrinsic motivation. The insufficient justification effect is from dissonance theory, not self-perception theory.

questions.stem: A clinical psychologist notices that a client who has been in psychotherapy for 6 months and invested considerable time, money, and emotional energy continues to rate the therapy as highly valuable despite minimal objective improvement in symptoms. Analyze this scenario using cognitive dissonance theory.

options.text: The client has invested substantial effort and resources into therapy
The client's symptoms have objectively improved
The therapist has used persuasion techniques to influence the client's evaluation
Effort justification -- valuing therapy more highly to justify the investment
Mere exposure effect -- familiarity with therapy increases liking
Classical conditioning -- therapy setting associated with positive reinforcement
The psychologist should use objective outcome measures rather than relying solely on client self-report to evaluate treatment effectiveness
The psychologist should increase the frequency of sessions to further enhance the client's positive evaluation
The psychologist should interpret the client's positive rating as evidence that therapy is working effectively

questions.explanation: This scenario illustrates effort justification, a cognitive dissonance paradigm. The client has invested substantial effort (time, money, emotional energy) in therapy (predisposing factor). The cognition 'I invested heavily in therapy' is dissonant with 'therapy hasn't helped,' so the client reduces dissonance by inflating the perceived value of therapy (central phenomenon -- effort justification). The clinical implication is that therapists should not rely solely on client self-report to evaluate treatment effectiveness, as effort justification can bias self-reports upward. Objective outcome measures provide a more accurate assessment of therapeutic progress.

questions.stem: A health psychologist designs an intervention to increase exercise behavior in sedentary adults. Using the Theory of Planned Behavior as a framework, analyze the key components of an effective intervention.

options.text: The individual's attitude toward exercise, perceived social expectations, and confidence in their ability to exercise regularly
The individual's personality traits and general health attitudes
The individual's past exercise behavior and current fitness level exclusively
Theory of Planned Behavior: attitude toward the behavior + subjective norms + perceived behavioral control -> behavioral intention -> behavior
Cognitive dissonance theory: creating inconsistency between health beliefs and sedentary behavior to motivate change
Self-perception theory: having people observe themselves exercising to infer positive exercise attitudes
Address all three components -- strengthen positive exercise attitudes, build social support for exercise, and enhance perceived behavioral control through graduated mastery experiences
Focus exclusively on providing information about exercise benefits to change attitudes, as attitudes are the strongest predictor
Use fear appeals about the consequences of sedentary behavior to create dissonance and motivate change

questions.explanation: The Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991) provides a systematic framework for behavior change interventions. Assessment should target all three TPB components: attitude toward the behavior, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control. The model predicts that behavioral intention (and ultimately behavior) results from the combined influence of all three components. An effective intervention therefore addresses all three: building positive exercise attitudes, enlisting social support (subjective norms), and enhancing perceived behavioral control through graduated mastery experiences (similar to building self-efficacy). Focusing on only one component would be insufficient.

questions.stem: In the following passage about self-perception theory and the overjustification effect, highlight ALL statements that contain factual errors.
questions.passage: Daryl Bem's self-perception theory (1972) proposes that when internal cues are weak or ambiguous, people infer their attitudes by observing their own behavior. | This theory was developed as a direct extension of Festinger's cognitive dissonance theory and makes identical mechanistic predictions. | A key prediction of self-perception theory is the overjustification effect, which states that providing external rewards for an intrinsically motivated activity can decrease intrinsic motivation. | Lepper, Greene, and Nisbett (1973) demonstrated this effect by showing that children who received an expected reward for drawing subsequently spent less time drawing during free play compared to children who received no reward. | The overjustification effect occurs because the person infers that they must have been performing the activity for the reward rather than for intrinsic enjoyment. | This effect is strongest when the external reward is unexpected and delivered after the behavior is completed.

highlightableSegments.text: Daryl Bem's self-perception theory (1972) proposes that when internal cues are weak or ambiguous, people infer their attitudes by observing their own behavior.
This theory was developed as a direct extension of Festinger's cognitive dissonance theory and makes identical mechanistic predictions.
A key prediction of self-perception theory is the overjustification effect, which states that providing external rewards for an intrinsically motivated activity can decrease intrinsic motivation.

Lepper, Greene, and Nisbitt (1973) demonstrated this effect by showing that children who received an expected reward for drawing subsequently spent less time drawing during free play compared to children who received no reward.
The overjustification effect occurs because the person infers that they must have been performing the activity for the reward rather than for intrinsic enjoyment.
This effect is strongest when the external reward is unexpected and delivered after the behavior is completed.

questions.explanation: Two statements contain factual errors: (1) Self-perception theory was NOT developed as a direct extension of cognitive dissonance theory -- it was developed as an ALTERNATIVE explanation that challenges dissonance theory's mechanism. While both theories make similar behavioral predictions, they propose fundamentally different mechanisms (calm inference vs. aversive arousal). (2) The overjustification effect is strongest when the reward is EXPECTED and offered BEFORE the behavior, not when it is unexpected. Unexpected rewards do not undermine intrinsic motivation because the person does not attribute their behavior to the reward. It is the expected reward that shifts the perceived cause of behavior from intrinsic to extrinsic.

questions.stem: In the following passage about cognitive dissonance reduction strategies, highlight ALL statements that contain factual errors.
questions.passage: When a smoker who believes smoking is harmful continues to smoke, cognitive dissonance is aroused because of the inconsistency between the behavior and the belief. | According to Festinger's theory, this dissonance creates a pleasant state of arousal that the person is motivated to maintain. | One strategy for reducing dissonance is to change the attitude to be consistent with the behavior, such as convincing oneself that smoking is not actually harmful. | Another strategy is to add consonant cognitions that bridge the inconsistency, such as 'I exercise regularly, which offsets the risk.' | A third strategy is to trivialize the inconsistency by minimizing its importance. | Research on cognitive dissonance has shown that dissonance is greatest when the person freely chose to engage in the counterattitudinal behavior and when the consequences of the behavior are foreseeable.

highlightableSegments.text: When a smoker who believes smoking is harmful continues to smoke, cognitive dissonance is aroused because of the inconsistency between the behavior and the belief.
According to Festinger's theory, this dissonance creates a pleasant state of arousal that the person is motivated to maintain.
One strategy for reducing dissonance is to change the attitude to be consistent with the behavior, such as convincing oneself that smoking is not actually harmful.
Another strategy is to add consonant cognitions that bridge the inconsistency, such as 'I exercise regularly, which offsets the risk.'
A third strategy is to trivialize the inconsistency by minimizing its importance.

Research on cognitive dissonance has shown that dissonance is greatest when the person freely chose to engage in the counterattitudinal behavior and when the consequences of the behavior are foreseeable.

questions.explanation: Only one statement contains a factual error: Segment 2 states that dissonance creates a 'pleasant state of arousal that the person is motivated to maintain.' This is incorrect. Cognitive dissonance creates an AVERSIVE (unpleasant) state of arousal that the person is motivated to REDUCE, not maintain. The uncomfortable tension is what drives the person to change their attitude, add consonant cognitions, or trivialize the inconsistency. All other statements accurately describe dissonance theory, its reduction strategies, and the conditions that maximize dissonance (free choice and foreseeable consequences).

questions.stem: Arrange the following events in the correct temporal/causal sequence as they occur in the induced compliance (insufficient justification) paradigm of cognitive dissonance:

items.text: Participant performs a boring, tedious task
Participant is offered minimal payment ($1) to tell the next participant that the task was enjoyable
Participant engages in counterattitudinal behavior (tells the next participant the task was fun)
Participant experiences cognitive dissonance because there is insufficient external justification for the lie
Participant reduces dissonance by changing their attitude, coming to believe the task was actually somewhat enjoyable

questions.explanation: The induced compliance paradigm follows a specific causal sequence: (1) The participant performs a boring task, establishing a negative attitude. (2) They are offered minimal payment ($1) to engage in counterattitudinal behavior. (3) They tell the next participant the task was fun (counterattitudinal behavior). (4) Because the payment is insufficient to justify the lie, dissonance is aroused between the cognitions 'I said the task was fun' and 'the task was boring.' (5) To reduce this aversive arousal, the participant changes their attitude toward the task, coming to genuinely believe it was more enjoyable. The minimal external justification is the key: with large payment ($20), there is sufficient justification and no dissonance is aroused.

questions.stem: Arrange the following steps in the correct sequence as they occur in the process of attitude-behavior prediction according to the Theory of Planned Behavior:

items.text: The person evaluates the behavior (attitude toward the behavior)
The person considers what important others expect (subjective norms)
The person assesses their capability to perform the behavior (perceived behavioral control)
These three components combine to form behavioral intention
Behavioral intention, moderated by actual behavioral control, leads to the target behavior

questions.explanation: The Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991) specifies a causal chain: Three antecedent factors -- attitude toward the behavior, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control -- combine to determine behavioral intention. Behavioral intention is the most proximal predictor of behavior, moderated by actual behavioral control. Note that (1) the TPB assesses attitude toward the specific behavior, not toward the attitude object in general, (2) perceived behavioral control also has a direct path to behavior (bypassing intention) when actual control is limited, and (3) the TPB is an extension of the Theory of Reasoned Action, which included only the first two components.

questions.stem: Based on cognitive dissonance research on the effort justification paradigm, which graph best represents the relationship between the amount of effort/suffering invested in attaining a goal and the subjective value placed on that goal?
questions.explanation: Effort justification research shows a positive curvilinear (accelerating) relationship between effort and perceived value. With minimal effort, there is little dissonance and therefore little need to inflate the value of the goal. As effort increases, the dissonance between 'I suffered significantly' and 'this goal is mediocre' becomes increasingly aversive, producing increasingly greater attitude inflation. The relationship accelerates because greater effort creates proportionally more dissonance, requiring greater attitude change for resolution. Research does not support an inverted-U; even extreme effort tends to increase perceived value (e.g., severe military training increases unit loyalty rather than producing resentment).
options: A positive linear relationship: as effort increases, perceived value of the goal increases proportionally
A positive curvilinear (accelerating) relationship: perceived value increases slowly at first with small efforts, then accelerates dramatically with greater effort investment
An inverted-U relationship: perceived value increases with moderate effort but decreases with extreme effort due to resentment
A negative linear relationship: greater effort leads to lower perceived value due to frustration and exhaustion

questions.stem: According to the overjustification effect research by Lepper, Greene, and Nisbett (1973), which graph best represents the relationship between intrinsic motivation for drawing and the introduction then removal of expected external rewards in children who initially enjoyed drawing?
questions.explanation: The overjustification effect shows a specific pattern: Children who initially enjoy drawing (high baseline intrinsic motivation) continue to draw during the expected reward phase (behavior is maintained by both intrinsic and extrinsic motivation). However, after the expected reward is removed, intrinsic motivation drops BELOW baseline levels. This occurs because the child reattributes their behavior from intrinsic ('I draw because I enjoy it') to extrinsic ('I draw because I get a reward'). When the reward is removed, the extrinsic justification disappears, but the intrinsic motivation has already been undermined by the reattribution process. Importantly, unexpected rewards do not produce this effect.
options: Intrinsic motivation remains stable across all phases (baseline, reward, post-reward) because external rewards have no effect on intrinsic motivation
Intrinsic motivation increases during the reward phase and remains elevated after the reward is removed
Intrinsic motivation is maintained during the reward phase but drops below baseline after the expected reward is removed
Intrinsic motivation drops immediately when the reward is introduced and returns to baseline when the reward is removed

questions.stem: Categorize each scenario as an example of the cognitive dissonance reduction strategy it best illustrates.

items.text: A smoker who believes smoking is harmful decides that the research on smoking and cancer is actually not that convincing
A smoker tells himself 'I exercise regularly, which compensates for any damage from smoking'
A smoker says 'Everyone has to die of something -- worrying about health is pointless'
A person who cheated on a test begins to believe that 'the test was unfair and didn't measure real knowledge anyway'
A person who cheated on a test reminds herself that she volunteers at a homeless shelter every weekend and is fundamentally a good person
A person who broke their diet says 'One slice of cake is no big deal in the grand scheme of things'

questions.explanation: Festinger identified three primary strategies for reducing cognitive dissonance: (1) Changing the attitude/cognition: The smoker decides smoking research is unconvincing, and the cheater decides the test was unfair -- both modify a cognition to reduce the inconsistency. (2) Adding consonant cognitions: The smoker adds 'exercise compensates,' and the cheater adds 'I'm a good person overall' (this latter example also reflects self-affirmation) -- both introduce new cognitions that reduce the perceived inconsistency. (3) Trivializing the inconsistency: The smoker minimizes the importance of health ('everyone dies') and the dieter minimizes the significance of one transgression ('no big deal') -- both reduce dissonance by decreasing the perceived importance of the conflict.

questions.stem: Categorize each attitude function described below according to Katz's (1960) functional approach to attitudes.

items.text: A consumer prefers Brand X because it consistently delivers high-quality products at a good price
A person holds strong political opinions because they help organize and make sense of complex social issues
A person with deep insecurity about their intelligence disparages academics as 'out of touch with real life'
An environmentalist prominently displays their views because being 'green' is central to their self-identity
A person develops a negative attitude toward a restaurant that repeatedly served them poor food
A person who feels inadequate in their career holds prejudiced views toward immigrants, perceiving them as threatening job opportunities
A religious person expresses strong moral opinions because they reflect deeply held spiritual values that define who they are
A voter uses party affiliation as a heuristic to evaluate candidates because it simplifies the complex information landscape

questions.explanation: Katz's four attitude functions: (1) Utilitarian: Attitudes that help maximize rewards and minimize punishments (Brand X preference for quality/value, avoiding a bad restaurant). (2) Knowledge: Attitudes that organize and simplify the world (political opinions making sense of complexity, party affiliation as simplifying heuristic). (3) Ego-defensive: Attitudes that protect against internal threats to self-esteem (disparaging academics due to intellectual insecurity, prejudice against immigrants driven by career inadequacy). (4) Value-expressive: Attitudes that express core values and identity (environmentalism as self-identity, religious moral views reflecting spiritual values). This framework is clinically important because effective attitude change requires targeting the function the attitude serves.
